description: Bwambale Robert  is  feeling happy with  Masereka Solomon  and  3 others  at  Kasese Humanist Schools . As religious zealots were thronging places of worship to memorize and remember a story they are told or read in a book, i was busy designing a website for the teachers who teach at my schools. its at  http://teachersatkasesehumanistschools.webs.com/  The purpose of this website is to notify the world that our school is determined to educate Ugandans as in accordance with the Ministry of Education and spicing the curriculum with vocational skills training, evidence based learning and computer skills.  At our schools we do not indoctrinate our learners to anything but we just want the learners to think freely, think for themselves, we promote critical thinking skills and creativity.  My intention is to bring my staffs in the limelight to the international community. I am not alone, i work with over 50 employees and would want the international community to try and link up with any of them and where possible try and contribute some tokens of appreciations for the services they render to the learners, also by standing bold to work for a school where many people out here out of ignorance make ignorant and unfounded statement which are all LIES and FAKE.  I have encouraged them to have online presence since we now live in a global village and each of them is free to interact with any like minded individuals or organizations worldwide.  With Science, we can progress. Bwambale Robert

description: Stella Nyanzi My body is weak because of illnesses I caught in prison. After intensive investigations of samples of my blood, urine, stool and sputum, my doctors confirmed that my blood pressure is high, and I have both malaria and a nasty urinary tract infection (UTI). I am now taking a huge cocktail of powerful medicines to heal my body and restore my strength.  I was horrified and ashamed to learn these test results. Malaria horrified me. The UTI shamed me. My doctors explained that the hygiene conditions in prison bathrooms and toilets are breeding places for such infections. Moreover, women's bodies are more prone to catching urinary tract infections than men's bodies.   What does it mean for a state to grab a person with a healthy body, dump and lock that person up in a space infested with infections, illnesses and diseases? Why must remanded suspects be dumped in prison wards festering with virii, bacteria, and other germs? Is the incaceration of women a facade for infecting them with diseases that wreck harvoc on their bodies? When a 'suspect' is remanded and kept in prison for safe custody, is infection with deadly illnesses part of the bargain? What are the meanings of incaceration for remands in this fucked up country? Samuel Oola Olara Stella Nyanzi Stella Stella Edgar Muvunyi Tabaro

description: Stella Nyanzi What a delight to be out of the ugly belly of the state's brutality! Luzira Women's Prison will forever hold a dear place in my heart. I made friends with prisoners. Thirty-three days of wearing the sickening yellow uniform, sleeping on a thin mattress spread on the cement floor - alongside sixty other in-mates in my ward, squatting in mock respect of underpaid prison warders, running to be locked up for 'Foleni' counts, undressing for body searches exposing my genitals to the prying eyes of warders, the nightmare of shitting in a flooding pit latrine, surveillance, interrogation, the works...   I am glad to be home with family and friends who love me. I am loved. I am grateful to be loved. All the days I was locked up in Uganda's beastly prison, I was upheld by love from near and far. I thank you all for the love. Freedom smells lovely when among loved ones.  My lawyers and legal team kept my winning spirit up. My sureties restored my hope in humanity. All my visitors in prison inspired me not to give up. The public press media and the social media fraternities kept the fire burning. Human rights activists, feminists, queers, journalists, cartoonists, comedians, musicians, artists, scholars, researchers, foreign missions, and all my allies who stood tall and proud in solidarity with me, I thank you. Stella Nyanzi Stella Nyanzi Nicholas Opiyo Stella Nyanzi Stella Nyanzi Ambrozio Barigye Wazabanga Mukiga Stella Nyanzi Stella Nyanzi Stella Nyanzi

Access to building materials is an obvious reason why Romans could build such impressive buildings.

As the people globally mark world Humanist Day, at the Rukoki Campus of Kasese Humanist School, it was a moment of joy and happiness as the pupils in all classes refrained from learning and had moment of happiness.  The children were happy being in a humanist school which highly respects human rights freedoms and values everything surrounding humanity.  In this one life we all share, the kids enjoyed dancing to their favorite tunes and enjoyed eating food plus some drinks.   The children themselves had longed for a social gathering of this nature and we had to coincide it with the the World Humanist Day to reflect on the goodness of Humanism and how it empowers humanity to Question everything.  The whole school participated in the event.  Attached are some of the images taken in the course of the event.  With Science, we can progress.

In this era of drought currently ravaging crops and drying them seriously.  The Bizoha Farmland is our rescue at the moment. I had initially planted some 2 acres of sweet potatoes and its our rescue this time.  Today, i got a full sack of sweet potatoes and delivered it to the Rukoki School to supplement on feeding the teachers and some boarders at the school.  The Bizoha Farmland is a stretch of land measuring 10 acres now of farmland with bananas, cassava, maize, greens, yams and so on located in the irrigation zone of Rutoke - Lower Muhokya.  Am so thankful to having planned procure this place in earlier years and am so relieved to having it safe a situation that could have been bad as far as supporting the dietary needs of my schools.  Attached are images of the harvests being delivered.  With Science, we can progress. Orphans at Kasese Humanist Primary School

Loving them and  ... giving them the best, improving their concentration and endurance thus humanism.   It was a great Friday with students learning about space exploration thus touring the International Space Station and reviewing "Expedition 45-Visiting Crew to the International Space Station" .  Schools are learning centers not worship centers, I hate indoctrination thus taking guess work for facts, mythology is dangerous for man to take as reality.  Good education is education that is balanced and comparative, think about critical thinking, thinking about the impact of the education that has stayed in your community for more than 10 years, what has your product done for society, thieves and crime is  high, ask yourself if you have been teaching thieves.   Positive progress is hard work, positive progress scares the some people that wish you bad. Defining a good school, defining good learning environment not worship centers, man needs good education not mythology.  I don't deal with sports alone, I give a variety to the young generation in order to have better societies now and in the future. This is part of my humanism, this is my life with children and their education. Don't just speak that language, understand that language.  "WITH SCIENCE, WE CAN PROGRESS" ~ Uplifting peoples minds! description: Bwambale Robert  added  8 new photos  ‚Äî  feeling strong with  Masereka Solomon  and  3 others  at  Kasese Humanist Schools . Primary Seven candidates at the Bizoha & Rukoki School have today concluded the 2 day mock examinations which were organised by the Kasese District Primary Schools Head Teachers Association.  This paper is a litmus test to learners preparing for their final examinations scheduled to take place in November. If they perform well in the final examinations , they will find their way into joining secondary school education.  Results for mock examinations will be out before the new term commences.  In a related note, tomorrow 25th August is closing day for Term Two and all our learners will be off for a 3 weeks holiday and will report back on 18th September 2017 for Term 3.  Attached are images of the mock exam environment at our school hall in Rukoki.  With Science, we can progress.

description: Bwambale Robert  added  8 new photos  ‚Äî  feeling thankful with  Masereka Solomon  and  5 others  in  Kahendero, Kasese, Uganda . Yesterday 18th October, a section students of the Geography class had an outdoor learning event and were studying about Fishing in Uganda and the focal point was an overview of what transpires at a fishing village.  The students were moved to the Kahendero Fish landing site under guidance of the School Head teacher accompanied by one of the teachers at Kasese Humanist Secondary School.  It was a good learning experience, at the landing site, a tour guide and a local explained to the learners the history of the Kahendero landing site, what transpires there, the associated problems at the landing site, the goodness and badness of the waters on this lake, a mention of breeding season and the richness in biodiversity of lake George, the types of fish caught in the lake and the mutual interdependence or coexistence of the lake, Queen Elizabeth National park to mention but a few.  The students boarded the floating classroom boat under driver ship of Mr Yasin who toured the students around the waters giving the students chance to look at the different flora and fauna on Lake George.  It was a wonderful experience and the students enjoyed the boat ride.  The whole exercise was funded by  Bwambale Robert  The School Director of Kasese Humanist Schools.  Attached are images as they unfolded.  With Science, we can progress.

Bwambale Robert  added  5 new photos  ‚Äî  feeling excited with  Masereka Solomon  and  2 others  at  Kasese Humanist Schools . It was a moment of joy at the Kasese Humanist School Rukoki campus where we received two smart ladies from Sweden who had lots of enthusiasm for sports.   The visitors came a long with our current volunteer at the school Robert Nygren who also hails from Sweden. They visited the Bizoha School in Muhokya, mingled with the learners and taught a class on a topic about Sweden as a country. They gave chance to our pupils to ask anything they want to know about Sweden.  Later on, the visitors visited the Bizoha Humanist Center where they had a 101 talk with the Kasese Humanist School Founder and discussed several issues all in all devising means on how best our school can go to greater heights.  The visitors visited Kahendero Humanist School where they had their lunch with the teachers there. It was a great fun indeed and a moment to involve mixed cultures.   At the Rukoki School, the visitors participated in soccer that was between girls and boys. This was a sign of equality which our school embrace and cherishes.  On behalf of the school management, it was a great pleasure hosting Jovana and Tina to our schools and look forward for a long lasting fraternity in our long journey of serving the nation in this one life we all share.  Attached are snapshots of the events!  With Science, we can progress.
